title: Minimum Spanning Tree Algorithm Visualizer
creator: Claude Code AI Assistant
subject: Computer Science
Graph Theory
Algorithms
Data Structures
description: Interactive visualization demonstrating Kruskal's and Prim's algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees in weighted graphs. Students can step through algorithm execution, compare approaches, and understand cycle detection in network optimization.
learningObjectives: Understand the minimum spanning tree problem and its applications
Compare Kruskal's edge-based and Prim's node-based algorithmic approaches
Analyze how greedy algorithms make locally optimal choices
Observe cycle detection mechanisms using union-find data structures
Apply graph theory concepts to real-world network optimization problems
prerequisites: Familiarity with greedy algorithms (helpful but not required)

accessibility.screenReader: ARIA labels provided via p5 describe() function
accessibility.colorblindSafe: High contrast colors used for edge states

controls.name: Algorithm Selection
controls.description: Choose between Kruskal's (edge-based) or Prim's (node-based) algorithm

controls.name: Step Forward
controls.description: Execute one algorithm step to observe decision-making process

controls.name: Reset
controls.description: Generate new random graph and restart simulation

controls.name: Animation Speed
controls.description: Control delay between algorithm steps for learning pace

variables: nodes - graph vertices with positions and labels
edges - graph edges with weights and states
mstEdges - edges accepted into minimum spanning tree
parent - union-find structure for Kruskal's cycle detection
visited - node tracker for Prim's algorithm
priorityQueue - candidate edges for Prim's algorithm
equations: MST weight = sum of all accepted edge weights
Greedy choice: min(available edges satisfying constraints)
assumptions: Graph is connected (all nodes reachable from any starting node)
Edge weights are positive integers (50-200 range)
8 nodes with ~15 edges provides good visualization
Both algorithms always find an MST (may differ in edge selection order)
limitations: Does not visualize internal data structures (union-find tree, priority queue)
Random graph generation may create varying difficulty levels
realWorldApplications: Supply chain and distribution network design
